newsitem.title: SOUTH AFRICA: S.Africa rand/bonds closing report.
newsitem.headline: S.Africa rand/bonds closing report.

text.p: The rand finished a touch firmer in thin dealings at the official close on Wednesday, but the currency and long bonds then weakened in thin after-hours dealings, traders said.
The local currency stood at 4.5685/5735 on the dollar at 1400 GMT from 4.5705/5755 at the Tuesday finish, but had slipped to 4.5730/80 by 1500 GMT.
"It was very quiet this afternoon. The rand stayed in a tight 4.5675-4.5750 range," a dealer said.
Traders said there had been light volume importer demand at the bottom of the range, while a handful of exporters had sold dollars at the top of the band.
In the morning, the rand succumbed to see-saw trade, starting off firmer on a weaker U.S. dollar overnight, exporter supply and long dollar position-squaring.
By noon, however, the local unit had retraced from its initial strength on offshore dollar demand sliding to a worst level of 4.5725 bid on the dollar early in the afternoon.
Dealers said they expected the rand to hold in a 4.5650-4.5750 band on Thursday.

Against the crosses, the rand was last at 7.2984/3110 on the British pound after falling to an all-time low of 7.3067 bid in after-hours trade on Tuesday. On the mark, the rand was at 0.3322/3327 from 0.3353/3357 previously.
Key long bonds were weaker in late trading, still depressed by disappointing consumer inflation data.
September CPI rose 1.0 percent month-on-month and 8.4 percent year-on-year in September. A Reuters poll of economists forecast a consensus 0.7 percent month-on-month and 8.1 percent annual rise.
Dealers said the market was suffering from a lack of interest.
At 1400 GMT the key R150 was 15.44 percent from 15.375 percent, but rose steadily to a worst level of 15.55 percent on a technical break by 1500 GMT, dealers said.
"When the key 15.45 percent level was broken, yields just went up. There has been selling from both offshore and local people," a dealer said.
After-hours dealings are generally thin, allowing for sharp movements in bond yields.
Bond Exchange figures show foreigners bought a net 36.29 million rand worth of South African bonds on Tuesday after selling a net 47.77 million rand on Monday.
Nominal cumulative volumes were pegged at 3.93 billion rand from 2.51 billion rand on Monday.
On the money market, three-month NCDs were steady at between 16.15 percent bid and 16 percent. The 90-day BA rate was unchanged at between 15.55 and 15.40 percent.
The Reserve Bank indicated the daily shortage at 7.629 billion rand on Tuesday from 8.0 billion rand on Monday.
